Ans3.

Hyperparameters are as follows:

For ridge:
The optimum value of lambda is 12.5
maxiter = 30000
lr = 0.00001
epsilon = 1e-4

For lasso:
The optimum value of lambda is 3.5e5
maxiter = 1000


The solutions are as follows:

 [-9.48969887e+01]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 2.15965304e+04]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [-7.99885040e+02]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]
 [ 6.42281278e+03]
 [ 0.00000000e+00]]

We can see from the plot that there is a optimum value of lambda for minimum loss. Below and above this value of lambda the loss increases. We can tell that at lower lambda we are not restricting the weights so our model overfits and at higher lambda the weights are too much restricted and as a result our model underfits.

Using these plots we can find the value of lambda which best minimizes the losses.

The minimized error is :
ridge : 540282958728.35034
lasso : 5.33e11   533781043521.64966

Ans5.

The solution of lasso assigns zero to a lot of variables as compared to ridge. This is unusual because in general regression its highly improbable that we get exact zero as one of the weight dimensions. This happens because the lasso loss function has a pointed shape (as given in the diagram in the webpage) and as a result the least loss contour is highly likely to touch the valid weight space at some corner of the allowed weight space and as a result assign 0 as most of the weight dimensions. 

The advantage of lasso is that it makes our weights simpler in the sense that the dimensions which were not contributing much in deciding the output are assigned a value of exact 0 and hence while predicting we wont consider the value along this dimensions (as if they represent noise).This potentially leads to better generalisation.
